note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction with endobronchial valve placement, left upper lobe.
Patient: Logan Pierce, 67-year-old male with severe heterogeneous emphysema and hyperinflation despite maximal medical therapy and pulmonary rehabilitation.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with endotracheal intubation (8.0 mm ETT).
Indication: Symptomatic severe COPD/emphysema with upper-lobe–predominant disease and hyperinflation, candidate for bronchoscopic lung volume reduction.
Pre-procedure imaging and physiology: High-resolution CT with severe LUL-predominant emphysema and intact left oblique fissure (>95% completeness). Quantitative perfusion with relatively preserved perfusion to contralateral lung. Baseline FEV1 32% predicted, RV 210% predicted.
Collateral ventilation assessment: Chartis balloon catheter deployed in the left upper lobe bronchus showed rapid flow decay to zero with plateau, consistent with absence of collateral ventilation.
Procedure details: Under general anesthesia, a therapeutic flexible bronchoscope was advanced through the ETT. The left bronchial tree was inspected and the LUL bronchus identified. Chartis measurements were obtained as above. A delivery catheter was then advanced, and four Zephyr endobronchial valves were placed sequentially in the apicoposterior, anterior, and lingular segmental bronchi to completely occlude the LUL. Valve positions were confirmed bronchoscopically and with fluoroscopy. After several minutes, there was visible reduction in LUL ventilation with improved excursion of the left hemidiaphragm.
Complications: Minimal self-limited oozing at one segmental orifice controlled with cold saline. No hypoxemia, hemodynamic instability, or immediate pneumothorax.
Disposition: Extubated in the bronchoscopy suite and transferred to step-down unit for post-BLVR monitoring with serial CXRs and telemetry.
Plan: Monitor for post-procedure pneumothorax for at least 72 hours. Continue bronchodilators and pulmonary rehab. Repeat spirometry and 6MWT at 3 months to assess response.

registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Severe upper-lobe–predominant emphysema with left upper lobe hyperinflation and intact oblique fissure
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Maximal inhaler therapy, pulmonary rehabilitation, long-term oxygen therapy
registry_entry.ventilation_mode: Volume control ventilation with low tidal volume strategy
registry_entry.nav_imaging_verification: Fluoroscopy confirming valve positions and reduced ventilation to LUL

registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Severe heterogeneous emphysema status post BLVR with successful LUL valve placement and early target lobe collapse
follow_up_plan: Telemetry and continuous oximetry for 72 hours
Daily CXR for 3 days to assess for pneumothorax and target lobe atelectasis
Outpatient PFTs and 6MWT at 3 months
Pulmonary rehabilitation to continue

coding_review.overall_assessment: Single-lobe BLVR with valve insertion only; no additional lobes or separate diagnostic procedures are coded.

coding_review.overall_assessment: Unilateral BLVR in a single lobe. 31647 encompasses the Chartis assessment when performed in the same session/lobe.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction with endobronchial valve placement, right upper lobe.
Patient: Patricia Morales, 63-year-old female with severe COPD and upper-lobe–predominant emphysema refractory to optimal medical management.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with laryngeal mask airway (size 4 LMA).
Indication: Symptomatic severe emphysema with marked RUL hyperinflation and exercise limitation despite guideline-directed COPD therapy.
Pre-procedure imaging and physiology: CT chest demonstrating severe heterogeneous emphysema with RUL-predominant disease and intact minor fissure. Perfusion scan with relative preservation of perfusion to contralateral lung. Baseline FEV1 29% predicted, DLCO 35% predicted.
Collateral ventilation assessment: Chartis assessment performed in the RUL bronchus demonstrated rapid flow decline to zero with stable plateau, consistent with absence of collateral ventilation.
Procedure details: A therapeutic flexible bronchoscope was advanced via the LMA. The right bronchial tree was inspected and the RUL bronchus cannulated. Chartis assessment confirmed suitability for BLVR. Three Zephyr endobronchial valves were then deployed in the apical, posterior, and anterior segmental bronchi. Valve positions were verified bronchoscopically and fluoroscopically. After several minutes of observation, there was decreased ventilation to the RUL and modest mediastinal shift toward the treated side, without hemodynamic compromise.
Complications: No significant bleeding. Transient mild hypoxemia during valve deployment, resolved with increased FiO2 and recruitment maneuvers. No immediate pneumothorax on post-procedure CXR.
Disposition: Recovered in PACU and admitted to monitored bed for routine post-BLVR observation.
Plan: Serial chest radiographs x 3 days, bronchodilators and incentive spirometry, outpatient PFTs at 3 months, and follow-up in BLVR clinic.

follow_up_plan: Monitored bed with continuous pulse oximetry for 48–72 hours
Daily chest radiograph x 3 days
Outpatient BLVR clinic visit at 4–6 weeks
PFTs at 3 months to quantify improvement

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with removal of endobronchial valves, right upper lobe, for post-BLVR pneumothorax.
Patient: Ethan Cole, 70-year-old male with severe emphysema status post RUL BLVR 5 days prior.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with endotracheal intubation (8.0 mm ETT).
Indication: Large right pneumothorax with persistent air leak and incomplete lung re-expansion despite chest tube drainage following recent RUL bronchial valve placement.
Background: The patient underwent RUL BLVR with three valves 5 days ago. On day 2 post-procedure, he developed a large right pneumothorax requiring chest tube placement. Despite appropriate chest tube position and suction, there was ongoing air leak and incomplete expansion of the RUL.
Procedure details: Under general anesthesia, a therapeutic bronchoscope was advanced through the ETT. The right bronchial tree was inspected. Three Zephyr valves were visualized in the RUL segmental bronchi with good seating. Given the persistent pneumothorax and continuous air leak, all three valves were removed sequentially using dedicated valve retrieval forceps. Each valve was grasped, collapsed, and withdrawn through the bronchoscope without difficulty. The underlying segmental bronchi were patent with mild mucosal edema but no active bleeding.
Complications: Mild oozing from one segmental takeoff controlled with topical epinephrine and cold saline. No immediate worsening of pneumothorax on post-procedure CXR; chest tube remained in place.
Disposition: Returned to step-down unit with chest tube on suction. Air leak decreased after valve removal.
Plan: Daily chest radiographs and monitoring of chest tube output and air leak. Consider chest tube removal once lung fully expanded and air leak resolves. No further BLVR planned on the right side.

registry_entry.bronch_guidance: Flexible bronchoscopy with fluoroscopic confirmation of valve removal

follow_up_plan: Daily chest radiographs until pneumothorax resolves

Resume COPD optimization and pulmonary rehab
Avoid further BLVR on right side; consider contralateral evaluation if clinically appropriate

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with removal of endobronchial valves, left lower lobe, for delayed post-BLVR pneumothorax.
Patient: Renee Thompson, 59-year-old female with severe emphysema status post LLL BLVR 2 weeks prior.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with endotracheal intubation (7.5 mm ETT).
Indication: Recurrent symptomatic left pneumothorax with persistent air leak and incomplete lung expansion despite appropriately positioned chest tube following recent LLL BLVR.
Background: The patient underwent LLL BLVR with four valves 14 days ago. She was discharged after an uncomplicated initial hospital course. She re-presented with pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea; CXR showed a moderate left pneumothorax, and a chest tube was placed. After several days on suction, there was persistent air leak and failure of the LLL to re-expand.
Procedure details: Under general anesthesia, a therapeutic bronchoscope was advanced through the ETT. The left bronchial tree was inspected. Four Zephyr valves were visualized in the basilar and superior segmental bronchi of the LLL. Given the persistent air leak, all four valves were removed sequentially using valve retrieval forceps. Each valve was collapsed and withdrawn through the scope without difficulty. The underlying bronchi demonstrated mild inflammatory changes but no purulence.
Complications: No significant bleeding. Oxygenation and hemodynamics remained stable. Post-procedure CXR showed improved LLL expansion with the chest tube in place and no increase in pneumothorax size.
Disposition: Returned to telemetry floor with chest tube to -20 cm H2O suction.
Plan: Daily chest radiographs; trial of water seal once air leak decreases; chest tube removal when lung fully expanded. No further BLVR planned for the LLL.

registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Moderate left pneumothorax with incompletely expanded LLL and chest tube in place

registry_entry.bronch_indication: Endobronchial valve removal for delayed BLVR-related pneumothorax

follow_up_plan: Daily CXRs to confirm progressive LLL expansion

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with adjustment and replacement of endobronchial valves, right upper lobe.
Patient: Marcus Hill, 65-year-old male with severe COPD status post RUL BLVR 6 weeks prior.
Anesthesia: Monitored anesthesia care with propofol and dexmedetomidine; LMA (size 4) airway.
Indication: Suboptimal lobar volume reduction and persistent RUL ventilation on imaging and physiology despite prior valve placement, suggesting malposition or incomplete occlusion of segmental bronchi.
Background: The patient underwent RUL BLVR with three Zephyr valves 6 weeks ago. Follow-up CT at 6 weeks showed only partial RUL volume reduction with persistent aeration of one segment. Spirometry demonstrated modest FEV1 improvement but persistent hyperinflation.
Procedure details: Under MAC with LMA, a therapeutic bronchoscope was advanced. The three existing valves were visualized in the RUL apical, posterior, and anterior segmental bronchi. The apical and anterior valves appeared well seated; the posterior valve was slightly proximal with visible ventilation around the valve. The posterior valve was removed using valve retrieval forceps (collapsed and withdrawn through the scope). A new, slightly larger Zephyr valve was then deployed more distally in the posterior segmental bronchus to achieve complete occlusion. A small amount of mucus around the apical valve was suctioned, and the apical valve was briefly removed and reinserted in a slightly more distal position to optimize seal. Final inspection showed all RUL segmental orifices fully occluded with valves in stable position.
Complications: Minimal mucosal oozing controlled with cold saline. No hypoxemia or hemodynamic instability.
Disposition: Observed in PACU and discharged to the floor on supplemental oxygen.
Plan: Repeat CT chest in 6–8 weeks to reassess RUL volume reduction and fissure completeness, repeat PFTs at 3 months, and close clinical follow-up in BLVR clinic.

registry_entry.radiographic_findings: CT showing only partial RUL volume reduction with persistent aeration of posterior segment 6 weeks post-BLVR
registry_entry.prior_therapy: RUL BLVR with three Zephyr valves 6 weeks prior
registry_entry.nav_imaging_verification: Follow-up CT planned to document improved volume reduction after adjustment

registry_entry.bronch_guidance: Flexible bronchoscopy under MAC with targeted valve removal and replacement
registry_entry.bronch_immediate_complications: Minor mucosal oozing controlled with cold saline
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Suboptimal RUL volume reduction due to partially malpositioned valve, improved after valve adjustment and replacement
follow_up_plan: Overnight observation with continuous pulse oximetry
CT chest in 6–8 weeks to reassess lobar volume reduction
PFTs at 3 months
BLVR clinic follow-up to determine long-term response

code_rationales.31647: Bronchoscopy with balloon occlusion/assessment and reinsertion of bronchial valve(s) in the same initial lobe to optimize lobar occlusion.

coding_review.overall_assessment: Combined removal and reinsertion of valves in a single initial lobe; 31648 and 31647 together model the adjustment and replacement work.

code_rationales.31647: Placement of replacement valve(s) in the Right Upper Lobe (initial lobe).

coding_review.overall_assessment: Valve exchange involves both removal and placement. Both 31648 and 31647 are supported when distinct work is performed.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with replacement of expectorated endobronchial valve and optimization of valve set, left upper lobe.
Patient: Alison Reed, 61-year-old female with severe heterogeneous emphysema status post LUL BLVR 3 months prior.
Sedation: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl; native airway with bite block.
Indication: Suspected valve loss after the patient reported coughing up an endobronchial valve at home, with subsequent increase in dyspnea and decline in exercise tolerance.
Background: The patient underwent LUL BLVR with four Zephyr valves 3 months earlier with good initial response. Over the past 2 weeks, she noted increased cough and exertional dyspnea and brought an expectorated valve to clinic. Spirometry showed loss of some of the initial FEV1 gain; CT demonstrated partial re-aeration of an LUL segment.
Procedure details: Under moderate sedation, a flexible bronchoscope was advanced through the mouth with bite block. The left bronchial tree was inspected. In the LUL, two valves were seen in stable position; one segmental bronchus (apicoposterior) was open without a valve, and one valve in the anterior segment appeared slightly proximal with visible ventilation around the frame. The proximal anterior valve was removed with retrieval forceps, collapsed, and withdrawn. A new Zephyr valve was deployed more distally in the anterior segment to achieve complete occlusion. A second new valve was then deployed in the apicoposterior segment to replace the expectorated valve. Final inspection showed three LUL segmental bronchi fully occluded with valves in stable positions.
Complications: None. No significant bleeding or hypoxemia.
Disposition: Observed for 2 hours post-procedure in bronchoscopy recovery and discharged home on baseline oxygen.
Plan: Clinic follow-up in 4–6 weeks with spirometry and symptom assessment; repeat CT at 3 months if clinically indicated.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Valve replacement and optimization after expectoration of one LUL BLVR valve and recurrent symptoms
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: CT showing partial re-aeration of one LUL segment with otherwise reduced lobar volume after prior BLVR
registry_entry.prior_therapy: LUL BLVR with four Zephyr valves 3 months prior; one valve reportedly expectorated
registry_entry.nav_imaging_verification: Pre-procedure CT demonstrating open segment; post-procedure imaging planned if clinically indicated
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Endobronchial valve replacement and optimization after valve loss
registry_entry.bronch_guidance: Flexible bronchoscopy under moderate sedation with valve removal and redeployment
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Loss of one BLVR valve with recurrent symptoms, improved after LUL valve replacement and optimization
follow_up_plan: Clinic follow-up in 4–6 weeks with spirometry
CT chest at 3 months if symptoms or PFTs suggest suboptimal response
Ongoing COPD management and pulmonary rehabilitation
